Nouse interviews nightclub photographer, Felix Wahlberg

11/02/2023

Nouse sits down with nightclub photographer and University of York student Felix Wahlberg.

Image by Annie Watson

By James Clay

As university life resumes following the Winter break, and students flock back to Yorkâ€™s nightlife post exams, Nouse sat down with nightclub photographer and University of York student Felix Wahlberg.

Felix has been working as a night-club photographer since Freshersâ€™ week last year. He has been interested in photography, he said, â€œstarting when I was five, or something...going out with my mum with a little film camera, mooch-ing around the garden."

From this, he went along to pursue A-Level photography before â€œin my leave of absence I started working at a landscaping company...which I quickly fell out of loveâ€ with.

In his free time Felix would still practise his hobby of photography, going out to â€œnearby cafÃ© squares and, what happened is, I was just bringing my camera along, taking a few photos of people."

Felix then â€œnoticed actually that with a lot of people, I was taking these photos, and then next thing you know it was on their Facebook profile page."

When Felix realised his work was gaining interest, â€œwhat I started doing was I would sit outside, take photos, and share around on Facebook and just put a watermark on it.

â€œI was charging Â£5 for a digital download but then for each one, Â£1 of that was going to Whiteknights York-shire Blood Bikesâ€, a Yorkshire-based charity made up of volunteer motorcyclists who transport blood samples and medication to the NHS free of charge.

Following this, he found his way into the YorPartyNetwork through a mutual friend and recognition for his prior work.

From there, Felix describes thatâ€œwhat it was actually was Freshersâ€™ last year, and because I knew I was going tobe doing the nightclub stuff, I was actually pretty keen to get out and do a bit of practice before doing my first paid job.â€

Felix stated that he gotâ€œquite luckyâ€ in â€œcoming along at a time where [Matthews] was looking to get out of thingsâ€.

When asked about his connection to and relationship with the individual clubs within York, Felix explained that he is self-employed, working with both York Parties and Illuminati, on UoY and YSJ club nights.

He also works with individual clubs such as Kuda and Club Salvationin house to provide photography when they are open. He has had previous experience with Popworld and Flares, who have since undergone a â€œchange in policy.â€

Felixâ€™s work is not only limited to York, however, extending to places such as Sheffieldâ€™s Leadmill and Leedsâ€™ PRY-ZM, whilst he also works from 3-5am in Doncaster every Saturday.

The most visually stunning, according to Felix, would be Kuda, particularly praising the clubâ€™s lighting. Felix then followed this up with Flaresâ€™â€œlovelyâ€ Wednesday night crowd and the outside element of Sunday Revs.

Personally, however, Felix gave Club Salvation the crown for which club he would personally enjoy on a night out due to its â€œhugeâ€ set up and thus the inevitability of â€œbumping intimatesâ€.

Following questions about his personal opinions, Felix described theâ€œclose knitâ€ nature of all who work in the York nightlife industry and his unique position of knowing everyone through his work at the different clubs.

He noted that he has a â€œdifferent perspectiveâ€ on door staff to many students, saying that â€œsome of the complaints can be quite unfoundedâ€. Felix also acknowledges that not everyone is perfect, however, and has even had to report door staff himself on occasion.

Despite this, Felix reaffirms the view that door staff are not â€œaggressiveâ€ and do â€œcare a lot about the image they give off â€, extending this praise also to the owner of Club Salvation.

Felix works â€œevery night of the week, seven nights a week and then most nights my average each night is around two hours a night, but then Saturday night for example, I do five hours that night between four different venues.â€

These anti-social hours tend to pay well, as compensated by the clubs, due to Felixâ€™s ability to set his own rates through self-employment.

This would also be due in part to the high demand for his job, with Felix noting how â€œa lot of people can take photos, but Iâ€™d say the secret sauce really is the editâ€.

As much as this element of the job has its positives, it can often lead to issues regarding work/life balance. To help with this, â€œwhat Iâ€™ve actually started doing at the moment is Iâ€™ve got some people on board helping me out nowâ€.

The goal for this term, Felix states,is to â€œget a little bit more balance, because as much as I love it...itâ€™s quite useful just having someone else onboard who can help outâ€. On occasion,â€œwhat theyâ€™ll do is theyâ€™ll photograph the actual event for me and then the following day Iâ€™ll then edit it for themâ€.

He explains that if this were the case, it could be â€œpotentially two, three, four venues that Iâ€™m letting downâ€. Furthermore, due to Felixâ€™s self-employment, if this were to happen, the clubs would have no responsibility over any damage endured by his kit.

However, thankfully, an incident such as this has not yet been the case.
